citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A bottle of artificial tears located in the cabinet storing medications expired in 2021. The licensee stated that he could not
remember when this medication was last used to treat the animals. Expired medications may not be effective in treating
disease conditions in animals and their use may be detrimental to animal health. The licensee should use appropriate
methods to prevent and treat illness in animals. This was corrected at the time of inspection.
Correct by 11-22-23

Two adult female pomeranians were found to have thinning hair coats and areas of thickened skin with complete hair
loss. The licensee stated that the veterinarian had examined the dogs and agreed that it would be appropriate to treat
both animals as outlined in the written program of veterinary care. The licensee stated that the dogs had been treated but
had no record of when the dogs were treated and what treatment method was used. There was no record of what date
the dogs were examined by a veterinarian or what the veterinarian's findings were. Failure to record veterinary
examination findings and recommendations and failure to record when treatments are given prevents APHIS officials from
determining whether the program of veterinary care is being followed. The treatments performed and the dates that
treatments were administered should be recorded and made available for APHIS inspection.
Correct by 11-23-23

The dates of administration is missing for when all adult dogs received a 5 day preventative Panacur treatment. The date
that the Panacur treatment was started was recorded but not additional dates for the other 4 days given. Medical records
must be complete for APHIS officials to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. Dealers, exhibitors,
and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS
inspection. These records must include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of
administration. This was corrected at the time of inspection.
To be corrected by: 11-22-23
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 21-January-2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
Additional Inspectors:
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A bottle of artificial tears located in the cabinet storing medications expired in 2021. The licensee stated that he could not 
remember when this medication was last used to treat the animals. Expired medications may not be effective in treating 
disease conditions in animals and their use may be detrimental to animal health. The licensee should use appropriate 
methods to prevent and treat illness in animals. This was corrected at the time of inspection. 
Correct by 11-22-23 
3.13(b)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Two adult female pomeranians were found to have thinning hair coats and areas of thickened skin with complete hair 
loss. The licensee stated that the veterinarian had examined the dogs and agreed that it would be appropriate to treat 
both animals as outlined in the written program of veterinary care. The licensee stated that the dogs had been treated but 
had no record of when the dogs were treated and what treatment method was used. There was no record of what date 
the dogs were examined by a veterinarian or what the veterinarian's findings were. Failure to record veterinary 
examination findings and recommendations and failure to record when treatments are given prevents APHIS officials from 
determining whether the program of veterinary care is being followed. The treatments performed and the dates that 
treatments were administered should be recorded and made available for APHIS inspection. 
Correct by 11-23-23 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The dates of administration is missing for when all adult dogs received a 5 day preventative Panacur treatment. The date 
that the Panacur treatment was started was recorded but not additional dates for the other 4 days given. Medical records 
must be complete for APHIS officials to ensure the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. Dealers, exhibitors, 
and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for APHIS 
inspection. These records must include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of 
administration. This was corrected at the time of inspection. 
To be corrected by: 11-22-23

This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 21-January-2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Paige Johnson, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOR n
